newsitem.title: UK: Amstrad to appeal Seagate ruling.
newsitem.headline: Amstrad to appeal Seagate ruling.

text.p: Amstrad Plc said on Tuesday it would appeal a court decision to award the British electronics group 85.45 million pounds ($144 million) in an alleged fraud case against U.S. hard disk drive manufacturer Seagate Technology Inc.

Amstrad, which is seeking a total settlement of around 105 million pounds on a claim dating back to 1989, was awarded 57 million pounds last month and the latest British hearing was to determine interest and costs.
"We will be appealing against the interest and tax calculations," a company spokesman said.

The company, which alleges that the U.S. group sold it faulty disk drives, also said it was meeting with its British and U.S. lawyers to consider bringing a new action in America against Seagate for punitive damages.
Under American law, a court can award four times damages as a punitive measure if cases such as fraud are proven.
"The lawyers are in a huddle at the moment," the spokesman said. "Litigation is, if nothing else, a slow process." However, a decision might be taken within a month, he said.

Amstrad, whose shares bucked a weak market trend and rose 2.5p to 286p, is also taking action against Western Digital Corp -- again for allegedly faulty disk drives. A hearing is set for later this year in California.

Amstrad, whose reputation under outspoken founder and chairman Alan Sugar has taken a roller coaster ride since the group reported its first losses in the early 1990s, announced a break-up plan earlier this month which will wipe the name from the stock market.
It will be replaced by a company called Viglen Technology. The Amstrad name will remain only as a Viglen subsidiary. ($ = 0.594 British Pounds)
